authors: Lucy Mae Beers For Daily Mail Australia
description: A scorned woman has posted pamphlets around Auckland, publicising her former Tinder lover's name, address and workplace after he 'tricked her into sleeping' with him.
title: Tinder warning poster shames man who tricked woman into sleeping with him
title_page: Tinder warning poster shames man who tricked woman into sleeping with him | Daily Mail Online
text:
A scorned woman has posted pamphlets to name and shame her former Tinder lover after he 'tricked her into sleeping' with him.
The woman, who prefers to remain unnamed, decided to publicise the pair's embarrassing relationship details as well as her former lover's name, address and workplace in a series of flyers titled 'Tinder Warning' and drop them in letterboxes around Grafton in Auckland, New Zealand.
In a bizarre twist, the address led to a local cafe where the man went for coffee 'once or twice a week,' Stuff.co.nz reported.
A scorned woman has posted pamphlets and posters (pictured) around Auckland to name and shame her former Tinder lover
The man has not returned to the cafe since the pamphlets surfaced on Wednesday.
The printed flyers were also posted on several poles in the area and showed a picture of the man wearing a baseball cap and holding a beer.
'I was going to move on but frankly I'm being very grumpy and nasty this last couple of days as I am depressed and hurt,' she wrote on the pamphlets.
'Frankly, having been tricked into sleeping with someone and then them getting to say every horrible degrading thing imaginable to you is kind of worse than rape in a lot of ways, and I didn't want to give you any more opportunities to hurt me.'
The Auckland woman also shared a message the man sent to her ending their relationship.
The woman, who prefers to remain unnamed, decided to publicise the pair's embarrassing relationship details (stock image)
The couple met on the popular dating application Tinder that uses location and age preferences to match potential couples
Auckland Police Senior Sergeant Danny Meade said he understands no complaint has yet been made regarding the pamphlets
'we just didn't click enough. I really am sorry about that,' he reportedly told her, stuff.co.nz reported.
Auckland Police Senior Sergeant Danny Meade said he understands no complaint has yet been made regarding the pamphlets.
He said although the flyers would fall under the Harrassment Act, the action would need to be a 'continued action.'
